_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary for OXARC, Inc.
1530 Dietrich Rd.
Pasco, WA 99301

Storage and Filling of Butane

1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
We are OXARC, Inc. are strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as receipt of containers and product, storage, and employee training associated with the chemicals at this facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. 

Under the "Accidental Release Prevention Program," responsibility for the proper handling and storage of flammable gases stored and used at this facility is given to the production manager and overseen by the Director of Safety and Compliance. Additionally, OXARC, Inc. senior management have responsibility to ensure facility managers and the Director of Safety and Compliance keep the program up-to-date and that all reports and findings are taken care of in a timely manner.

2.	The Regulated Substances Handled
The facility is typically unoccupied except for when filling processes take place. There is only one substance at this facility above the threshold quantity: butane in a bulk storage tank with a capacity of 11,900 gallons, as well as empty and full butane 20 lbs. and 100 lbs. cylinders. The maximum amount on hand is approximately 50,000 pounds. Butane is filled at this facility out of the bulk storage tank and into the cylinders which are then distributed to our wholesalers and retail facilities for sale.

3.	General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
This facility has taken all of the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at this facility.

Pr

ocess Safety Information
OXARC, Inc. maintains safety information that describes the chemical hazards, handling, storage, and usage of the regulated substance at this facility.

Process Hazard Analysis
This facility conducts reviews to ensure that hazards associated with the handling, storage, and filling of cylinders are identified and controlled efficiently. Any findings related the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA review was preformed upon installation, 8/4/2015.

Operating Procedures
For the purpose of safely handling, filling, and storing cylinders, OXARC, Inc. has written procedures that address the production of filling butane.

Training
OXARC, Inc. has a comprehensive program in place to ensure employees who are responsible for the handling of hazardous substances are competent in the procedures. Refresher training is provided on an ongoing basis.

Mechanical Integrity
OXARC, Inc. takes great care in ensuring that the structural integrity of the containers and cylinders is maintained throughout the handling and storage of these containers, cylinders, and any equipment associated with the process.

Management of Change
The most recent review/revision of procedures was performed on 10/08/2015. Employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in the operating procedures are promptly made aware of and trained in these changes.

Compliance Audits
This is the facility's first appropriation of a covered process and therefore a compliance audit is yet to be completed.

Incident Investigation
OXARC, Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could result in an unintentional release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
OXARC, Inc. believes that safety manag

ement and accident prevention is a team effort. OXARC employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of this facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from any hazard analyses.

Contractors
On occasion, OXARC, Inc. hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety of the contractor is carried out. OXARC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractors work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release occur.

4.	Five-Year Accident History
This is the initial submission for the covered process. Therefore, there is no accident history to report.

5.	Emergency Response Plan
OXARC, Inc. has an Emergency Action Plan in lieu of an Emergency Response Plan due to the few employees on-site during operations. The plan includes all required aspects of the Action Plan and was created using "OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Expert System". The plan identifies alerts, what to do in the event of an emergency, evacuation, extinguishers, operations, employee duties, and meeting points and accountability.

Franklin County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee covering this facility.

6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
OXARC, Inc. has no plans at the present time.
